May 25, 2014: Fiction
UNLUCKY 13, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown.) With the
return of a killer who was presumed dead, the San Francisco detective Lindsay
Boxer and the Women’s Murder Club take action.
FIELD OF PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam.) Lucas Davenport investigates
when multiple bodies are found in the middle of the Minnesota cornfields.
WALKING ON WATER, by Richard Paul Evans. (Simon & Schuster.) In the fifth
and final book of the “Walk” series, Alan reaches Key West.
THE TARGET, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central.) As the government hit man
Will Robie and his partner, Jessica Reel, prepare for a mission, they face a new
adversary.
THE GOLDFINCH, by Donna Tartt. (Little, Brown.)  A painting smuggled out of the
Metropolitan Museum of Art after a bombing becomes a boy’s prize, guilt and
burden.
NATCHEZ BURNING, by Greg Iles. (Morrow/HarperCollins.) Penn Cage, a former
prosecutor in Natchez, Miss., delves into the secrets of his father, a doctor who
has been accused of murdering an African-American nurse.
THE COLLECTOR, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam.) A writer travels the world of
affluent art collectors to learn the truth about what appears to be a murder/suicide.
CHESTNUT STREET, by Maeve Binchy. (Knopf.) Binchy, who died in 2012,
depicts ordinary lives in Dublin.
THE INVENTION OF WINGS, by Sue Monk Kidd. (Viking.) The relationship
between a wealthy Charleston girl, Sarah Grimké, who will grow up to become a
prominent abolitionist, and the slave she is given for her 11th birthday.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World
War II, when their paths eventually cross.
DELICIOUS!, by Ruth Reichl. (Random House.) The food writer and editor’s first
novel concerns a woman who finds herself when the magazine where she works
closes.
MIDNIGHT CROSSROAD, by Charlaine Harris. (Ace.) Secrets lurk in a small
Texas town; the start of a new series.
ROBERT B. PARKER'S CHEAP SHOT, by Ace Atkins. (Putnam.) Spenser
searches for the kidnapped son of a player for the New England Patriots; a
continuation of the series by Parker, who died in 2010.
Non-Fiction
CAPITAL IN THE TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY, by Thomas Piketty.
(Belknap/Harvard University.) A French economist’s analysis of centuries of
economic history predicts worsening inequality and proposes solutions.
FINDING ME, by Michelle Knight with Michelle Burford. (Weinstein.) The story of a
woman kidnapped in Cleveland in 2002, then tortured, who escaped in 2013.
THE CLOSER, by Mariano Rivera with Wayne Coffey. (Little, Brown.) A memoir
by the great Yankees pitcher.
EVERYBODY'S GOT SOMETHING, by Robin Roberts with Veronica Chambers.
(Grand Central.) A memoir by the “Good Morning America” anchor discusses her
struggle with breast cancer and a rare blood disorder.
A FIGHTING CHANCE, by Elizabeth Warren. (Metropolitan/Holt.) The
Massachusetts senator describes her life, her academic work and her battle for a
consumer protection agency.
GOOD CALL, by Jase Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard Books.) The
second-oldest son of the Robertson family from the A&E show “Duck Dynasty”
shares anecdotes and reflections on his faith.
FLASH BOYS, by Michael Lewis. (Norton.) The world of high-frequency computer-
driven trading.
THRIVE, by Arianna Huffington. (Harmony.) Personal well-being as the
indispensable third measure — with money and power — of success.
JAMES MADISON, by Lynne Cheney. (Viking.) A biography of the fourth president
and advocate for the Constitution.
LET'S JUST SAY IT WASN'T PRETTY, by Diane Keaton. (Random House.) The
actor discusses aging, beauty and her personal style.
LEAN IN, by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf.) The chief operating
officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.
DAVID AND GOLIATH, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown.) How disadvantages
can work in our favor.
JOHN WAYNE: THE LIFE AND LEGEND, by Scott Eyman. (Simon & Schuster.) A
biography of the movie star surveys his life, his death and his legend.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House.) An Olympic runner’s story
of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
